tree.speaker: OO
tree.text: Green technology needed to fully eliminate carbon footprint likely does not yet exist.

children.speaker: OG
children.text: Monetary policy can funnel capital quickly into green businesses, incentivizing faster development.

children.speaker: CG
children.text: Central bank policy reduces fossil fuel industry viability, enhancing green tech growth potential.

children.speaker: CO
children.text: Companies will aggressively downsize and harm vulnerable workers during restructuring.

children.speaker: OO
children.text: Economic harm from rapid divestment outweighs speculative long-term green benefits.

children.speaker: OG
children.text: Big polluters have money and patents but stall green tech for profit motives; central bank incentives align private and social interests.

children.speaker: CG
children.text: Angel investors prefer tech and pharma with higher returns over speculative green tech.

children.speaker: OO
children.text: Polluting industries can't diversify quickly due to costs, resource dependence, and lack of R&D.

children.speaker: OO
children.text: Developing nations rely on polluting industries for economic growth; cutting investment leads to economic collapse and poverty.

children.speaker: OG
children.text: Client relationships and regulation prevent companies from simply switching banks to avoid green mandates.

children.speaker: CO
children.text: Inflation disproportionately harms the poor and vulnerable, outweighing speculative green investment benefits.

children.speaker: CG
children.text: Developing world can develop without natural resources; central bank policy avoids propping up exploitative industries.

children.speaker: OO
children.text: Green tech investments are already attractive; new central bank policy mainly diverts funds to neutral, low-profit sectors.

children.speaker: CG
children.text: Central bank action solves collective action problem and ensures sustainable jobs for future generations.

children.speaker: OG
children.text: Central banks act independently and without political lobbying, unlike governments.

children.speaker: CO
children.text: Central bank climate action reduces political will for broader climate policies by creating complacency.

children.speaker: OO
children.text: No alternative investments exist in developing countries, risking long-term economic and environmental harm.

children.speaker: OG
children.text: OO contradict themselves by claiming green investment is already high but also causing unemployment harm.

children.speaker: CO
children.text: Inflation and economic instability primarily harm the most vulnerable by reducing purchasing power and control.

children.speaker: CO
children.text: Economic harms to workers and inflation outweigh speculative climate benefits; economic stability must be prioritized.

children.speaker: OO
children.text: Many polluting industries remain dependent on fossil fuels due to colonial legacies and resource advantages.

children.speaker: CG
children.text: Government intervention is limited and less effective without central bank support.

children.speaker: CO
children.text: Monetary policy is slow, indirect, and limited in effectiveness compared to political/regulatory action.

children.speaker: OO
children.text: Central bank policies cutting favorable rates to polluting industries cause immediate job losses and economic shocks.

children.speaker: OG
children.text: Central banks have historically shifted priorities and can shift to support green policies without huge disruption.

children.speaker: CO
children.text: Central bank green policies politicize climate action, reducing public support and political will.

children.speaker: CG
children.text: Political action is blocked by lobbying and partisan opposition, making central bank intervention necessary.

children.speaker: OG
children.text: Climate disaster is urgent with worsening impacts and slow government action.

children.speaker: CG
children.text: Private sector unwilling to invest significantly in green tech due to high startup costs and risks.

children.speaker: OO
children.text: Private actors, not governments, are the main investors in green tech due to growth potential and lowered entry costs.

children.speaker: CO
children.text: Large economic restructuring causes inflation and market shifts, contradicting OGâ€™s claim that expert investors prevent this.

children.speaker: CG
children.text: Angel and venture investors are financial illiterate on green tech due to risks and short-term focus.

children.speaker: OG
children.text: Central bank policy changes cost of borrowing, directly pressuring companies to shift business models.

children.speaker: OG
children.text: Green investments are attractive to private equity and pension funds when supported by central bank policies.

children.speaker: CO
children.text: Inflation control and market stability are central bank priorities and will be harmed by green mandates.

children.speaker: OO
children.text: Rapid divestment leads to job losses, reduced infrastructure development, and less food security in vulnerable countries.

children.speaker: CG
children.text: Private sector collusion with fossil fuels prevents structural change without central bank mandates.

children.speaker: CO
children.text: Companies will cut costs and abuse workers rather than transition to green technology due to restructuring costs and uncertainty.

children.speaker: CG
children.text: Negative interest rates are viable and central banks have significant market influence.

children.speaker: OG
children.text: Green central banking creates jobs, aids developing countries, and aligns economic and environmental goals.
